entry.summary: 亲身体验使用 iPhone 捕捉空间视频并使用 Vision Pro 观看。
entry.content:
昨天，苹果发布了 iOS 17.2 的开发者测试版 2 ，这是第一个支持使用 iPhone 15 Pro 机型捕捉空间视频的 iOS 版本。今天发布了公开测试版，启用了相同的功能。苹果昨天邀请我去纽约，不仅是预览使用 iPhone 捕捉空间视频，还体验使用 Vision Pro 观看这些空间视频。

就像我 6 月份在 WWDC 上第一次进行 Vision Pro 演示一样，这次体验令人惊叹。

在 iPhone 上捕捉空间视频

在 iPhone 15 Pro 上拍摄空间视频非常简单。该功能（至少目前）默认处于禁用状态，可以在“设置”→“相机”→“格式”中启用。该选项被标记为“Apple Vision Pro 的空间视频”，这是恰当的，因为（至少现在）空间视频仅在 Vision Pro 上播放时看起来与非空间视频不同。在任何其他设备上观看时，它看起来就像普通的平面视频。

启用后，只要处于常规视频模式，您就可以在相机应用程序中切换空间视频捕获。它非常类似于拍摄静态照片时的实时照片切换，或视频的动作模式切换 - 不是相机主水平模式切换器中的单独模式，而是主视频模式中的切换按钮。

捕捉空间视频时，您无法选择分辨率、帧速率或文件格式。所有空间视频均以 1080p、30 fps 的 HEVC 文件格式捕获。 1您还需要水平握住手机，使两个拍摄镜头处于同一平面。 iPhone 在拍摄空间视频时使用主镜头（1×）和超广角镜头（0.5×）进行捕捉，事实上，苹果改变了 iPhone 15 Pro 上三个镜头的排列，部分是为了支持这一功能。 （在之前的 iPhone Pro 机型上，水平握持时，超广角摄像头位于底部，主镜头和长焦镜头位于顶部。）

我认为分辨率仅限于 1080p，因为要从超宽 0.5× 相机获取与主 1× 相机相同视场的图像，需要大幅裁剪超宽图像。超广角相机只有 12 MP 传感器，因此没有足够的像素来从传感器中心裁剪 1 倍等效视野并获得 4K 图像。

使用 iPhone 拍摄空间视频有两个缺点。首先，前面提到的 1080p 分辨率和 30 fps 帧速率。多年来我一直默认拍摄 4K 视频，为什么不呢？我希望我们能够捕捉 4K 的空间视频，但遗憾的是，目前还没有。拍摄空间视频的第二个缺点是，与非空间 1080p 相比，它实际上使文件大小增加了一倍，原因很明显，每个空间视频包含两个 1080p 视频流。文件大小加倍只是一个很小的代价——视频仍然小于非空间 4K 30 fps 视频。 2

确实，在 iPhone 上捕捉空间视频没什么大不了的。如果切换按钮关闭，您可以使用所有常规选项的分辨率 (720p/1080p/4K) 和帧速率 (24/30/60) 捕获常规视频。如果空间视频的开关处于打开状态（打开时为黄色，不可能错过），您将失去这些选择，但它看起来就像捕捉普通视频一样。当您播放它或与在手机或计算机等常规设备上观看它的其他人分享它时，它看起来就像一个普通的平面视频。

如果您拥有 iPhone 15 Pro，那么今年没有充分的理由不开始捕捉空间视频（例如这个假期），以记录您可能想要体验的“回忆”的任何时刻。未来的Vision耳机，即使你明年不打算购买第一代Vision Pro。

在 Vision Pro 上查看空间视频

在演示之前，我向 Apple 提供了我的眼镜处方，并且我使用的 Vision Pro 耳机配备了适当的矫正镜片。与我六月份的演示一样，我通过耳机看到的一切看起来都非常清晰。

自 6 月份以来，Apple 显着改进并简化了入门/校准流程。在几个步骤中，您会看到一系列漂浮在您面前的大圆圈中的点，就像时钟上的小时索引一样。当您查看每个圆圈时，它会亮起一点，然后您会做出手指点击手势。 Vision Pro 采用这种方式来校准它认为您正在查看的内容就是您实际正在查看的内容。校准步骤完成后（只花了一两分钟）我就准备好进入 VisionOS 的主屏幕了。 （而且这种校准的精确度是惊人的——UI 元素可以放置得相对靠近，并且它准确地知道你在点击时正在看哪一个。iOS UI 设计需要比我们相对较粗的指尖更加宽容。 VisionOS UI 设计需要考虑到我们视线的精确度。）

我昨天的演示明确限于一般摄影，特别是空间视频，因此，根据 Apple 的要求，我的演示仅限于 VisionOS 中的照片应用程序。有时，我很想看看我还能去哪里、还能做什么。但仅在“照片”中就有太多可看可做的事情，以至于我的演示（佩戴 Vision Pro 总共大约 30 分钟）很快就过去了。

在我们使用 Vision Pro 将我们分开在较小的房间里之前，我与《华尔街日报》的乔安娜·斯特恩 (Joanna Stern) 配对，简要介绍了使用 iPhone 15 Pro 进行空间视频捕捉的细节。我们每人都获得了一部演示版 iPhone，并被允许拍摄我们自己的空间视频。我们在一个宽敞的现代高天花板厨房里，沐浴在大窗户的自然光中。一位厨师正在忙着准备寿司，并充当我们拍摄的模特。当然，乔安娜和我在互相拍摄的同时也拍摄了彼此的镜头。这是非常元的。我们自己拍摄的镜头随后被预加载到我们用于演示的相应 Vision Pro 耳机上。

我们不被允许在 Vision Pro 上捕捉空间视频。 3然而，我们的演示设备的照片库中有一个在 Vision Pro 上拍摄的视频 — 我之前在 6 月份经历过一段视频，内容是一群二十多岁的年轻人晚上围坐在火坑旁，在篝火旁玩耍。寒冷的气氛。还有其他几个由 Apple 拍摄的空间视频，这些视频是使用 iPhone 15 Pro 拍摄的。

一个明显的问题是：使用 iPhone 15 Pro 拍摄的空间视频与使用 Vision Pro 本身拍摄的空间视频有何不同？鉴于苹果只提供了一个在 Vision Pro 上拍摄的空间视频示例，我觉得根据我昨天的经历，我无法完全回答这个问题。差异似乎并不显着或显着。我体验过的使用 iPhone 15 Pro 拍摄的空间视频，包括我自己拍摄的视频，看起来与使用 Vision Pro 拍摄的视频一样出色。

苹果不会直接说出来，但我确实感觉到，综合考虑，使用 Vision Pro 捕捉的空间视频会“更好”。 iPhone 可能会在图像质量上胜出，因为 iPhone 15 Pro 上的 1× 主摄像头是苹果制造的最好的相机系统，但 Vision Pro 应该会在空间感（ 3D 性）上胜出，因为 Vision Pro 的两个用于空间视频捕捉的镜头彼此之间的距离大致与人眼的距离一样远。当然，iPhone 上用于拍摄的两个镜头之间的距离比人眼的距离要近得多。但是，尽管两个镜头彼此距离有多近，但在 iPhone 上拍摄的空间视频中，3D 效果仍然非常引人注目。不知怎的，它看起来既非常自然又完全不可思议。

观看它们的效果令人惊叹，体验非凡。因此，总的来说，iPhone 将成为空间视频的“最佳”捕捉设备——即使 Vision Pro 捕捉的镜头在技术上更优越——因为，正如古老的格言所说，最好的相机就是你拥有的相机与你。我几乎到处都带着 iPhone。对于明年的 Vision Pro 来说，这一点永远不会接近真实。

以下是我在 6 月份第一次实践 Vision Pro 后写的关于空间视频的文章：

空间照片和视频（使用 Vision Pro 本身拍摄的照片和视频）被视为 2D 内容和完全沉浸式 3D 内容之间的混合体。它们不会出现在明确定义的矩形中。相反，它们的周围有一层朦胧的梦幻般的边界。就像哈利波特电影中的某种隐形传送魔法咒语之类的。这种效果让我想起史蒂文·斯皮尔伯格的《少数派报告》 ，汤姆·克鲁斯饰演的角色会着迷地观看他儿子的“记忆” ，以及通灵的“预知者”感知即将发生的谋杀的幻象。这就像观看一个梦，但通过一个门户打开了另一个世界。

当您使用 Vision Pro 观看常规（非空间）视频或查看常规静态摄影时，图像会出现在您面前的清晰定义的窗口中。空间视频根本不是这样的。今天我无法比六月更好地描述它：这就像观看和聆听一个梦，通过一个朦胧的边界门户打开了另一个世界。

有几个因素造成了这种梦幻般的感觉。空间视频看起来并不真实。看起来或感觉起来这些拍摄对象并不真实地出现在您面前。您在 Vision Pro 中看到的实时直通视频以及您周围的真实世界都是如此。真实现实的直通视频是如此引人注目、如此逼真，以至于在我迄今为止的两次演示体验中，我忘记了我总是在我眼前的屏幕上观看视频，而不仅仅是用我的护目镜观看。眼睛对我周围世界的看法。

因此 Vision Pro 能够呈现看起来完全真实的视频 - 因为这正是直通视频的工作原理和感觉。录制的空间视频有所不同。一方面，现实不是 30 fps，也不是只有 1080p。这使得空间视频本身看起来并不低分辨率或粗糙，而更像电影。升级后的 1080p 图像呈现出电影般的颗粒感，明显低于现实的帧速率也传达出电影般的感觉。当然，更高的分辨率看起来会更好，但我不确定更高的帧速率会更好。电影和电视的魅力之一在于 24 和 30 fps 的镜头具有梦幻般的效果。

然而，您在屏幕上看过的任何内容都无法让您为观看这些空间视频的体验做好准备，尤其是那些您自己、家人和朋友拍摄的视频。它们确实更像是回忆而不是视频。我昨天体验的由苹果拍摄的空间视频看起来更好——由专业摄影师拍摄，并由专业演员出演。但我自己开枪的那些更引人注目，让我惊叹不已。我的朋友乔安娜就在我面前，就像我可以伸手触摸她一样，但那是 30 分钟前，在另一个房间。

当你经历这种情况时，准备好在情感上被感动吧。

全景照片和静态照片

我昨天的简报和演示体验主要是关于在 iPhone 15 Pro 上捕捉空间视频并在 Vision Pro 上观看，但我的演示经历了 VisionOS 中的整个照片应用体验。

普通的旧静态照片看起来棒极了。您可以将查看照片的虚拟窗口的大小调整为您实际需要的大小。这不仅仅是像拥有一个 20 英尺的显示器——其尺寸更接近于电影院屏幕而不是电视。这就像拥有一个具有视网膜质量分辨率的 20 英尺显示器，以及您使用过的任何显示器中最好的亮度和清晰度。我花了很多时间在 iPhone 显示屏上查看自己用 iPhone 拍摄的静态照片，很难相信它们放大到广告牌般的尺寸后看起来会有多好。只是用 iPhone 拍摄的普通静态照片。

然后还有全景照片。苹果公司在 2012 年推出 iPhone 5 时首次引入了全景模式。这个功能给我的印象从来没有比“一个很酷的技巧”更好的了。自该功能推出以来的十年里，我只使用了大约 200 个。当在平面显示器上观看时，它们看起来太不自然，光学扭曲太多。而且你把它们做得越全景，当平面观看时它们看起来就越不自然。

使用 Vision Pro 查看的全景照片令人惊叹。

完全没有光学畸变，没有鱼眼效果。看起来就像您站在拍摄全景照片的地方一样，拍摄时的全景视野越宽，播放体验就越引人注目。这太不可思议了，现在我希望在过去的 10 年里我能学到更多这样的东西。

作为基本规则，今后我计划拍摄人们的空间视频，尤其是我的家人和最亲爱的朋友，以及我访问过的地方的全景照片。这就像隐形传送。

杂项观察

Vision Pro 体验高度依赖于注视点渲染，维基百科将其简单地描述为“一种渲染技术，它使用与虚拟现实耳机集成的眼动追踪器，通过大幅降低周边视觉（在视觉之外）的图像质量来减少渲染工作量。中央凹注视的区域）。”我们的视网膜也是这样工作的——我们实际上只能清晰地看到落在视网膜中心黄斑上的东西。 Vision Pro 实际上只能以高分辨率渲染我们直接注视的内容。其余部分的分辨率较低，但这不是问题，因为当您转移视线时，Vision Pro 更新显示的速度非常快。

昨天我注意到，如果我将目光从一侧足够快地转移到另一侧，我就能捕捉到它更新的注视点。就在最短暂的时刻，您可能会以不太完美的分辨率捕获某些内容。我认为。它追踪你的目光并更新显示的速度是如此之快，我无法确定。然而，整体效果的细节和高分辨率令人难以置信。昨天我的演示仅限于照片应用程序，但我比以往任何时候都更有信心，Vision Pro 将成为一款出色的阅读和写作设备 - 因此，好吧，工作。

耳机带中扬声器的音质令人印象深刻。 Vision Pro 的视觉体验是如此引人注目——我的意思是，该产品的名称中含有“Vision”是有原因的——音频体验很容易被忽视，但它非常好。

通过凝视和手指点击来导航 VisionOS 是如此自然。我使用 Vision Pro 总共花了大约一个小时，分为两个 30 分钟的演示，但我已经对使用该操作系统感到很自在了。这是一种非常自然的交互模型，仅基于您所看到的内容。我对这个平台以及空间计算的未来充满热情。

  1. HEVC 规范允许单个文件包含多个视频流。这就是苹果正在做的事情，用元数据描述哪个流是“左”，哪个流是“右”。 Apple 早在 6 月 WWDC 结束后就发布了此格式的初步文档。 ↩︎

  2. 根据苹果公司的说法，这些是每分钟视频的平均文件大小：

    • 常规 1080p 30 fps：65 MB
    • 空间 1080p 30 fps：130 MB
    • 常规 4K 30 fps：190 MB ↩︎︎

  3. 释义：

    “这是数字王冠。今天您将使用它来通过旋转它来调整沉浸感，如果您需要返回主屏幕，您可以按下表冠。另一侧是用于使用 Vision Pro 拍摄照片或视频的按钮。我们今天不会使用那个按钮。”

    “但是那个按钮有用吗？如果我按下那个按钮，它会拍摄照片或视频吗？”

    “请不要按那个按钮。” ↩︎︎

entry.title: ★ Vision Pro、空间视频和全景照片
“iOS 17.2 暗示从 App Store 外部侧载应用程序”
entry.content:
Filipe Espósito，为 9to5Mac 提供了一个不错的独家新闻：

通过分析新的API，我们了解到它在系统中声明了一个扩展端点，这意味着其他应用程序可以创建这种类型的扩展。进一步挖掘，我们发现了一个新的、未使用的权利，它将授予第三方应用程序安装其他应用程序的权限。换句话说，这将允许开发者创建自己的应用程序商店。

该 API 具有用于从外部源下载、安装甚至更新应用程序的基本控制。它还可以检查应用程序是否与特定设备或 iOS 版本兼容，App Store 已经这样做了。同样，这可以很容易地用于现代化 MDM 解决方案，但这是另一件事。

我们还在该 API 中发现了区域锁定的引用，这表明 Apple 可以将其限制在特定国家/地区。这对于 MDM 解决方案来说没有意义，但只有在当局要求时（例如在欧盟），才可以在特定国家/地区启用侧载。

说得通。如果苹果最终被迫在欧盟允许侧载，我认为他们只会在欧盟允许。苹果仍有待上诉，但我怀疑他们会赢，合规截止日期是明年 3 月，这可能意味着 iOS 17.3 或 17.4。

★

entry.title: 今天的抖动：Vision Pro 上的空间视频预览

entry.summary: These new 14- and 16-inch MacBook Pros are the best laptops ever made. Not just the best MacBooks, the best laptops, full stop, and I don't think it's even close.
entry.content:
I'm glad that two weeks ago I griped about the complexity of the current iPad lineup . Three Pencils that are compatible with a complicated matrix of iPad models. iPad Pro models with the front-facing camera on the short side, but a 10th-generation non-pro iPad that's been updated with a front-facing camera on the long side, where pro users want it. It's a jumble.

I'm glad because now I have something to point to as a counterexample, a broad product lineup that is, with the introduction of the M3 family of chips, nearly perfect: MacBooks. Here's how I see Apple's lineup: 1

  • Budget: 13-inch M1 MacBook Air: $999
  • Consumer: M2 MacBook Air:
    • 13-inch: $1,100
    • 15-inch: $1,300
  • Pro Jr.: 14-inch M3 MacBook Pro: $1600
  • Professional Pro: M3 Pro MacBook Pro
    • 14-inch: $2,000
    • 16-inch: $2,500
  • Workstation-Class: M3 Max MacBook Pro
    • 14-inch: $3,200
    • 16-inch: $3,500

This lineup is clear, crisp, and good. MacBook Airs in the $1,000–$2,000 range; MacBook Pros with M3 Pro in the $2,000–$3,000 range, and MacBook Pros with the M3 Max in the $3,000– $yowza range. (A maxed-out 16-inch MBP with M3 Max (16-core CPU, 40-core GPU), 128 GB RAM, and 8 TB SSD costs $7,200.)

The wildcard in Apple's MacBook lineup is what I'm cheekily calling the “Pro Jr.” model. For the last few years, that's been the 13-inch MacBook Pro with Touch Bar — a laptop that most expert users thought shouldn't even exist, but which Apple has stated was the company's second-best-selling laptop. There are a lot of buyers who want a MacBook Pro, even if they don't need — or want to pay for — truly professional performance specs.

With the introduction last week of the 14-inch MacBook Pro with the regular M3 chip, Apple has fixed this tier. I often note that Apple means several different things when it describes a product as “pro” — it sometimes means professional , but sometimes means nicer or better . The regular M3 MacBook Pro exemplifies this latter meaning. It has the same industry-best 14-inch display as its M3 Pro and M3 Max siblings, the same excellent 6-speaker sound system, and the same modern form factor. It is, by all appearances, a MacBook worthy of the name “MacBook Pro” heading into 2024. 2

One key difference between the new 14-inch M3 MacBook Pro and the 13-inch M2 MacBook Pro it replaces in the lineup is price: the 13-inch M2 MBP started at $1,300; the new 14-inch M3 MBP starts at $1,600. That's a significant jump, but it makes sense. First, the new-ish 15-inch M2 MacBook Air — introduced this year at WWDC in June — now occupies the “starts at $1,300” tier in the price matrix. Second, it is named “Pro”.

The M3 Pro and M3 Max

With the M1 and M2 generations of Apple Silicon, consumer-level Macs debuted months ahead of the professional models with the Pro and Max (and for desktop systems, Ultra) variants of the chips:

  • The M1 chips debuted in November 2020 with the MacBook Air, 13-inch MacBook Pro, and Mac Mini . These Macs all had unchanged form factors from their Intel-chip predecessors.

  • The M1 Pro and Max, along with the new 14- and 16-inch “notched display” form factors, debuted almost a year later in October 2021 .

  • The M2 chip debuted in July 2022, in the new-form-factor 13-inch MacBook Air . That M2 chip also appeared in the 13-inch MacBook Pro with Touch Bar at the same time.

  • The M2 Pro and Max debuted in updated 14- and 16-inch MacBook Pros (along with the M2 Pro in a Mac Mini) in January of 2023 . The general consensus is that these machines were late, and were originally intended for late 2022, but the fact is they shipped in January this year.

So with the M1 generation, the Pro and Max models shipped almost a year after the plain M1. With the M2's, the Pro and Max models shipped about 6 months after the plain M2.

Now, with the M3 generation, the M3, M3 Pro, and M3 Max debuted alongside each other, and the plain M3 is debuting only in the new $1,600 “Pro Jr.” 14-inch MacBook Pro. All things considered, this makes sense: you'd think that the first laptops to get a new generation of chips would be the premium ones, not the consumer-priced ones. I suspect that what we saw with the M1 and M2 generations was a byproduct of Apple silicon being new — that the nature of launching a new PC chip architecture was such that Apple went with the “easier” chips first, the “harder” chips after. But now that they've been around this block a few times, having successfully bootstrapped an entirely new PC architecture, they've reached the point where they're able to lead with their most important M-series chips: pro chips for pro MacBooks.

I expect that we'll see M3 MacBook Airs in the spring, either at a special event in March or April, or at WWDC. 3 And that's probably the same time we'll see the desktop lineup — Mini, Studio, and Pro — move to the M3 series as well. (Even if the M3 Ultra is “just” two M3 Maxes bridged together, that should be a pretty good chip, with up to 32 CPU cores, 80 GPU cores, and a RAM cap of 256 GB. If the M3 Ultra is more than that... get your popcorn.)

Further, I think this will be the pattern henceforth, for the M4, M5, and future generations: MacBook Pros first, then MacBook Airs and desktops after. It simply makes more sense marketing-wise. The MacBook Pros are the performance-optimized laptops, and pro laptops far outsell pro desktops.

With the M1 and M2 generations, the Pro chip was basically half of a Max chip. That's not true with the M3 chips. In broad strokes, the M3 Pro is more like a beefed up regular M3, and the M3 Max is a different beast entirely. Looking at CPUs, split by performance and efficiency cores, here are the best configurations for each chip:

  • M3: 4/4
  • M3 Pro: 6/6
  • M3 Max: 12/4

The M3 Pro models are geared toward what I think is the sweet spot for MacBook Pro buyers, with a balance between performance and efficiency cores. The M3 Max models are clearly geared toward professionals who demand the highest performance available. 16 total CPU cores doesn't sound like that many more than 12, but the M3 Max cores aren't split evenly between performance and efficiency — they're skewed heavily toward performance cores.

There are also lesser (presumably, binned ) variants of the M3 Pro (11 total CPU cores: 5 performance cores/6 efficiency; 14-core GPU) and M3 Max (14 total CPU cores: 10 performance, 4 efficiency; 30-core GPU). And the RAM options for all of these chips vary, both in bandwidth and capacity:

  • M3: 2 RAM chips, 100 GB/s memory bandwidth:
    • 2 × 4 GB = 8 GB
    • 2 × 8 GB = 16 GB
    • 2 × 12 GB = 24 GB
  • M3 Pro: 3 RAM chips, 150 GB/s memory bandwidth:
    • 3 × 6 GB = 18 GB
    • 3 × 12 GB = 36 GB
  • M3 Max with 14-core CPU: 3 RAM chips, 300 GB/s memory bandwidth:
    • 3 × 12 GB = 36 GB
    • 3 × 32 GB = 96 GB
  • M3 Max with 16-core CPU: 4 RAM chips, 400 GB/s memory bandwidth:
    • 4 × 12 GB = 48 GB
    • 4 × 16 GB = 64 GB
    • 4 × 32 GB = 128 GB

Those RAM options also make clear that the M3 Pro is more like a beefed-up regular M3, and the M3 Max a different beast. The M3 Pro offers options with a little more RAM that's 1.5× faster than the baseline M3. The M3 Max offers options with a lot more RAM that's 3× or 4× faster.

At first it might seem overwhelming to see that the “M3 family of MacBook Pros” supports RAM tiers of 8, 16, 18, 24, 36, 48, 64, 96, and a whopping 128 GB of RAM. But once you zero in on a specific CPU, you've really only got two or three choices for RAM. My only complaints about RAM:

  • It would be nice if the base M3 model started at 16 GB, not 8 GB. 8 GB doesn't feel “pro” in any sense of the word. But we can't ignore Apple's profit margins and the siren song, marketing-wise, of hitting lower price points. Keeping the profit margins the same but bumping the base RAM to 16 GB would mean the entry model would start at $1,800; keeping the price at $1,600 but bumping the RAM to 16 GB would eat significantly into the margins for that model — which model, again, is Apple's second-best-selling Mac. We all love to spend Tim Cook's money, but he's the one who's been running the most profitable company in the world for over a decade. If you're offended by a mere 8 GB of RAM, pony up the extra $200.

  • I personally fall into the category where my number one performance need is RAM, because I tend to keep open dozens of apps and hundreds of Safari tabs. In terms of my CPU and GPU needs, I don't think I'd notice the difference between an M3 Pro and M3 Max. But to get a shitload of RAM (that's a computer science term), you need to buy an M3 Max model. I wish the M3 Pro had at least one more RAM configuration, say, 3 × 16 GB = 48 GB. That would still leave the 64-GB-and-up configurations to the M3 Max, but would be a nice option for people whose biggest power-user need is RAM.

None of these extreme options come cheap. The 14-inch MacBook Pro with the 16-core M3 Max and 40-core GPU starts at $3,700; the 16-inch model with the same chip starts at a cool $4,000. The base RAM for that chip is 48 GB — which is double the maximum RAM of the regular M3. Upgrading from 48 to 64 GB RAM costs $200 (a veritable pittance for a roughly $4,000 computer); upgrading from 48 to 128 GB, though, costs $1,000.

Performance

I've spent the last five days testing a 14-inch MacBook Pro with the M3 Max, with the 16-core CPU, 40-core GPU, 64 GB RAM, and a 2 TB SSD. That's a $4,300 configuration. Not cheap, but you really do get what you pay for: this machine absolutely screams.

My favorite benchmark is the browser-based Speedometer (currently version 2.1). Web browser rendering is surprisingly resource-intensive — partially because modern HTML, CSS, and Javascript are remarkably complex, and partially because most web developers are remarkably untalented and careless programmers. 4 Javascript is a single-threaded language, and so web browser rendering is inherently bound to the single-core performance of your CPU. Multi-core performance is important, but for most tasks for most users, single-core performance is more important. Speedometer measures that. My results, averaged over multiple runs:

The M1 Max MacBook Pro I'm using for comparison — my own — has 10 cores (8 performance, 2 efficiency) and 64 GB RAM. Both machines are running MacOS 14.1 Sonoma. (Point of comparison: my iPhone 15 Pro scores about 325 on the same Speedometer 2.1 benchmark. The days when iPhones outperformed MacBook Pros at single-core performance ended with the Intel era.)

Geekbench 6 results:

Factor 1.24× 1.84× 2.71×

These results are, broadly speaking, in line with each other, with the exception of the GPU discrepancy between Geekbench and Cinebench. I suspect Cinebench's 2.7× difference will prove more representative of real-world results, but that's just a hunch. But it seems fair to say that the M3 Max — and the M3 generation overall — is “faster enough”. These are very solid improvements from comparable MacBook Pros in just two years.

Apple's own marketing materials make several points of comparison to Intel-based Macs, which is where the new MacBook Pros truly shine. That's not entirely fair to Intel, the company, because Intel's laptop chips have, of course, gotten faster since Apple last shipped new Macs equipped with them in 2019. But it's completely relevant to all Mac users still using Intel-based Macs, who, according to people I've spoken with at Apple, remain a majority of the Mac user base. The upgrade cycle for Macs is long — more like that for cars, than for phones. Those Mac users who've held off on upgrading to Apple silicon hardware are in for a treat when they do.

I will note that the only time I've heard fan noise from the M3 Max MacBook Pro was while running Cinebench's benchmarks. The machine was warm, not hot, but the fan was definitely audible. Cinebench's are long-running benchmarks, each taking 10 minutes. In actual usage, I haven't heard the fans even once, as usual for an Apple silicon Mac.

Space Black

My review unit is, unsurprisingly and thankfully, space black — a new color option that is only available with the M3 Pro and M3 Max models. All of the new M3-series MacBook Pros are available in silver, but the dark option for the regular M3 models is the same old space gray.

Apple's product photography is very fair in terms of accurately conveying just how dark this “space black” is — which, despite its name, is a very dark gray, not black. Why not black black, though? Apple has made plenty of aluminum devices that are truly black. The iPhone 7 — available in both glossy jet black and matte black — comes to mind. I can only presume that this is the darkness that Apple thinks looks best for a MacBook Pro — that any darker would look worse, overall. There's a part of me that would like to see it even darker, but this is dark enough that I can believe that even darker would not look better.

I adore it. My personal Mac is a space gray 14-inch M1 Max MacBook Pro with 64 GB RAM (the maximum RAM allotment for that machine). I have no legitimate performance-related reasons to upgrade to an M3 Max MacBook Pro, but I want to, very much, simply because I crave this space black finish. Side by side, this space black M3 MacBook Pro makes my space gray M1 MacBook Pro look like silver. Space gray MacBooks are merely dark er . Space black, though not black, is actually dark . It's a superficial aspect, but it matters. If it didn't, Apple would just make them all silver and call it a day.

One reason, it seems, that the space gray Apple offered for years, on both MacBooks and iPads, wasn't darker is that darker shades of anodized aluminum are more prone to showing fingerprints. Visible fingerprints are a common complaint regarding the “midnight” M2 MacBook Airs, for example, which are in fact quite dark. When introducing the new space black option last week, Apple specifically mentioned a new process they've developed to reduce the visibility of fingerprints. It is not a coating. It is instead a “breakthrough chemistry” that is part of the anodization process. It doesn't feel any different at all to the touch, and it really does seem to alleviate the visibility of fingerprints. I'm calling it a legit breakthrough. I've not once cleaned this MacBook Pro's surface since I've been using it, and other than some squint-and-you-can-see-them smudges on the palm rest area, there's not much sign it's been used.

Also: the MagSafe power cable is black, and it looks cool as hell. If Darth Vader charged that chest plate dingus with MagSafe, this would be his cable.

结论

These new 14- and 16-inch MacBook Pros are the best laptops ever made. Not just the best MacBooks, the best laptops, full stop, and I don't think it's even close. They look great and feel great. They have excellent keyboards and the best trackpads in the world. For the power they pack, they're remarkably thin and light. They're durable. They offer a great assortment of ports, including three Thunderbolt 4 ports ( but just two ports on the 14-inch base model — the one with the regular M3 — and those two ports are Thunderbolt/USB 4, not Thunderbolt 4), HDMI out, an SD Card slot, and MagSafe. There is even a very small circular port where you can connect headphones that use a wired connection. The displays are the best in any laptops in the world, with great color accuracy and remarkable brightness. The speaker systems sound too good to be true for laptops.

That's all been true for two years now, since the M1 Pro and M1 Max MacBook Pros launched in October 2021.

Now they're even better: the M3 family of chips is more than just a speed bump from the M2. Apple has designed three entirely different chips for three different tiers of users. They're faster at single-core performance, faster at multi-core, and the GPUs introduce three breakthroughs: hardware accelerated ray tracing and mesh shading (new to Apple silicon), and a new memory allocation technique they're calling Dynamic Caching (new to the industry, so claims Apple). I suspect this explains the extraordinary gain in Cinebench's GPU benchmark comparing the M3 Max against my very comparable 2021 M1 Max. Apple's M-series silicon team is simply on fire, doing some of the most impressive work in the history of computer architecture design and engineering. PC laptops in this class weigh over 6.5 pounds and offer terrible battery life; the 16-inch MacBook Pro weighs 4.7–4.8, the 14-inch MacBook Pro just 3.4–3.6, and all offer remarkably long battery life. It's not like Apple's silicon team had one breakthrough moment back in 2020 and have since been regressing to the mean — they continue to increase their lead over the rest of the industry in performance-per-watt. The difference between Mac and PC laptop hardware is as vast and stark as the difference between MacOS and Windows software. Perhaps even more so.

So should you buy one?

Anyone who bought an M2 MacBook Pro earlier this year: I feel for you. First round of drinks is on me.

Anyone, like me, who bought an M1 MacBook Pro two years ago: you are right to feel tempted. If you're hell-bent on keeping your wallet in your pocket and waiting one more generation before upgrading, do not — I repeat, do not — let your eyes fall upon a space black M3 MacBook Pro.

Anyone still holding onto an Intel-based MacBook Pro: place an order right now, if you haven't already. I'm jealous of the treat you're in for when you experience what these premium Apple silicon machines are like to use.

I see “$1,100” and I know what it means; I see “1,099” and I need a moment to put it in context, and that context is understanding that it effectively means $1,100. I left the M1 MacBook Air at $999 in the above table because that's clearly a magic price point — Apple's only sub-$1,000 MacBook. ↩︎

  2. Pour one out for the Touch Bar, which many Mac users seemingly despised, but which I always had mixed feelings regarding. It wasn't good enough, that's clear. I think it needed haptic feedback, for one thing — something that would've enabled you to use it by touch alone. The name “Touch Bar” sort of didn't fit, if you think about it. Yes, it was a touch screen, but unlike the physical keys of a keyboard, there was no way to use it by feel alone. And it wasn't part of the display — it was part of the keyboard . You had to stare at it to use it. And the lack of a third dimension — buttons you could feel and that needed to be pressed, not just touched, to activate — made it prone to accidental activations. It was worth a try. I genuinely appreciate the ambition of trying something innovative with the F-key row. But it wasn't good enough and stuck around too long with that “Pro Jr.” 13-inch MacBook Pro. I'd love to see it return someday, with an implementation that somehow offers depth — a third dimension that you can feel and click. Something meant for your fingers, not your eyes. ↩︎︎

  3. I do not think we will see any M3 chips other than the regular M3 in the next generation of MacBook Air. Generally speaking, if a component has “pro” in its name, it goes into products with “pro” in their name. So I don't expect the M3 Pro will appear in a MacBook Air. It is true, though, that today's Mac Mini can be configured with an M2 Pro. The difference between the Mac Mini and MacBook Air, though, is cooling. The Mac Mini is relatively spacious and has fans; the MacBook Air is designed to be as thin as possible and has no fans. No fans means no M3 Pro, I suspect. ↩︎︎

'Matthew Perry Was the Sarcastic Soul of “Friends”'
entry.content:
Alan Sepinwall, writing for Rolling Stone:

There's not a lot of Matthew Perry in the pilot episode of Friends , but he gets to deliver one of its funniest jokes. As the gang sits around Central Perk, a newly-divorced Ross admits that he just wants to be married again. A second later, Rachel wanders into the coffee shop, soaking wet and wearing a wedding dress. Without missing a beat, Perry's Chandler Bing declares, “And I just want a million dollars!”

Like a lot of Chandler punchlines, it's quick and biting in its sarcasm. And like a lot of Chandler punchlines, Perry's delivery elevates it from a smartass quip that a few dozen actors could say into something you can't imagine leaving anyone else's mouth.

Note the timing and the emphasis of the thing. The pause after “And I,” the way he hits the “I” as hard as he does, and the way his voice goes full game show host as he says “million dollars,” all combine to give the gag a musicality beyond what Friends creators Marta Kauffman and David Crane wrote on the page. It's a small moment in an episode that is primarily concerned with characters who are not Chandler Bing. But you watch it and you want to hear him say things like it, again and again and again.

Perry was so great on Friends , but my favorite show he was on was the short-lived Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip , a 2006 Aaron Sorkin show that I've always thought failed in part * because it was a few years ahead of its time. Its lone 22-episode season aired on NBC. It was too smart, too cinematic, for network TV. It should have been on a cable channel like HBO, or, if it aired a decade later, a streaming service. The show was so good (at times — 22 episodes was way too many for a show striving for such quality), and Perry was sublime.

Perry, too, deserves accolades for his remarkable openness regarding his long struggle with addiction, and his heartfelt willingness to help anyone and everyone else with The Problem.安息。

* I don't know if it hurt Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip , but another weird thing about it was that it debuted the same year, on the same network, as Tina Fey's hall-of-fame-funny sitcom 30 Rock . Both shows shared the same fundamental premise: they were about fictionalized versions of Saturday Night Live . They even both had numbers in their titles, and those numbers were oddly similar. Studio 60 was a funny drama, and 30 Rock a sitcom's sitcom, but I always wondered if it was a bad idea to launch two roman a clefs about SNL at the same time.

entry.title: 'Matthew Perry Made It Look Easy'
entry.content:
Alexis Soloski, writing for The New York Times:

A confession: When I received a news alert that the actor Matthew Perry had died, my mind adopted the particular cadence that Perry perfected as Chandler Bing, the character he played for 10 seasons on the NBC sitcom Friends . Here is what I thought, “Could this be any sadder?”

Perry, 54, died nearly a year after the publication of Friends, Lovers, and the Big Terrible Thing , an unusually candid memoir of addiction and recovery. As he detailed in that book, he spent many of the best years of his career oblivious, avoidant, numb — conditions that don't typically encourage great acting. But he was great. And it had seemed reasonable, if rose-colored, to hope that sobriety might make him better, returning him to the nervy, instinctive brilliance of his peak years. That hope is now foreclosed. [...]

To say that he never did anything quite as good as Friends , before or after, is not to diminish his achievement. Even among the irrepressible talents of his co-stars, Perry stood out, for a rubbery, heedless way with physical comedy and a split-second timing that most stopwatches would envy. If you have seen more than a few episodes of the show — and many, many millions have, including fans born years after its initial airing — you will have absorbed Chandler's rhythms, his catchphrases, the way Perry's handsome, moony face would stretch like spandex, the better to sell a reaction. He had both an absolute commitment to what a line required and a way of gently ironizing that line. His character was the butt of jokes. Perry was in on those same jokes. There was a boyishness to him that seemed to excuse his characters' worst behavior, on Friends and in subsequent roles.

entry.title: iOS 17.2 (Beta) Sticker Reactions Stink
entry.content:
Jason Snell, writing at Six Colors on the new “use an emoji as a sticker reaction in Messages” feature in iOS 17.2, which just came out today as a public beta:

Instead, to send a sticker response you have to tap and hold on a message and then choose Add Sticker from the resulting contextual menu, then choose a sticker or emoji. It's an extra step that really shouldn't be necessary and makes stickers feel like an afterthought, which they apparently are.

It gets worse. When you add a sticker reaction, it's placed on top of the message you're reacting to, obscuring part of the text! Why in the world would Apple choose a placement that makes it impossible to read the text being responded to? The right placement for these reactions is … wait for it … the same place that Tapbacks appear, in a little bubble snuggled up against the message that's being reacted to.

This design feels more than a bit spiteful to me. I suspect there are two contingents inside Apple: the “ Tapbacks are perfect just as they are ” side (who prefer there are only six of them — heart, thumbs-up, thumbs-down, ha-ha, “!!”, and “?” — and who insist that they're monochrome), and the “ Jesus H. Christ, every single other popular messaging platform in the world lets users react with any emoji they want, in full color ” side. This new emoji-as-stickers feature is a small win for the latter contingent, but the Tapbacks-are-perfect side is calling the shots, and keeping Tapbacks as the only reactions that (a) are super-easy to apply, and (b) don't obscure the text of the message.

I've been playing with the feature, and the one emoji I've found that only barely obscures the text of the message it's applied to just happens to be the perfect emoji to express my feelings about how this feature currently works: 🖕.

★

entry.title: Google Spends $26 Billion Annually to Be the Default Search Engine Almost Everywhere (and Most of It Goes to You Know Who)
entry.content:
David Pierce, writing for The Verge:

The US v. Google antitrust trial is about many things, but more than anything, it's about the power of defaults. Even if it's easy to switch browsers or platforms or search engines, the one that appears when you turn it on matters a lot. Google obviously agrees and has paid a staggering amount to make sure it is the default: testimony in the trial revealed that Google spent a total of $26.3 billion in 2021 to be the default search engine in multiple browsers, phones, and platforms. [...]

Just to put that $26.3 billion in context: Alphabet, Google's parent company, announced in its recent earnings report that Google Search ad business brought in about $44 billion over the last three months and about $165 billion in the last year. Its entire ad business — which also includes YouTube ads — made a bit under $90 billion in profit. This is all back-of-the-napkin math, but essentially, Google is giving up about 16 percent of its search revenue and about 29 percent of its profit to those distribution deals.

Most of that money, of course, goes to Apple. The New York Times recently reported that Google's deal to be the default search engine in Safari across Google products cost the company about $18 billion in 2021.

Goldman Sachs analysts have been estimating this number for years, and $18 billion in 2021 is pretty much in line with their estimates. (Goldman conservatively estimates about $17 billion in TAC payments from Google to Apple for this year, 2023. That would be the low end — Apple gets at least that much from Google for their partnership on this.)

Apple reports this revenue under Services, which has just grown past $20 billion per quarter for Apple. So somewhere between 20-25 percent of Apple's Services revenue comes from these payments from Google alone. You can see why Apple is rooting for Google in this lawsuit.

This whole partnership with Google is the weakest link in Apple's overall privacy stance. Google generates so much money from search through user tracking that Apple would consider contrary to its own internal values. If Apple were to run its own search engine, it would be far more private than Google Search. But instead they partner with Google, set Google as the default for Safari on all platforms, and share in Google's profit to the tune of around $20 billion/year.

★

entry.title: The Aftermath of a Massacre Is Always the Time to Push for Gun Legislation
entry.content:
Axios:

New House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.) told Fox News' Sean Hannity in his first interview as speaker that now is not the time to discuss legislation to address the scourge of mass shootings, adding: “The problem is the human heart, not guns.”

Since no other civilized country on the planet has massacres like this, Johnson is implicitly arguing that the problem isn't the human heart, but the American heart.

Or, maybe the problem is the fact that America is the only country where military-grade assault rifles are not just legal, but legally obtainable by mentally ill angry men like this lunatic in Maine.

Either we are the worst people on the planet, or we have the worst gun laws.

Why it matters: President Biden and Democrats in Congress are urging action in the wake of the shooting in Lewiston, Maine that left 18 people dead. Johnson argued that it was inappropriate to discuss gun control “in the middle of the crisis,” and that he believes, “it's not the weapon, it's the underlying problem.”

This “ now is not the time ” argument gets trotted out by Republicans after each and every gun massacre. Right after their tweets offering “thoughts and prayers”. Bullshit. The aftermath of a massacre is the time to demand sane gun control measures. That's when the issue is clarified. Would Republicans argue that October 8 was “not the right time” for Israel to discuss Hamas terrorism? Was September 12, 2001 “not the right time” to discuss Al-Qaeda? Should FDR have delivered an address to the nation on December 8, 1941, advising that we relax, let cooler heads prevail, because the aftermath of Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor “was not the time” to consider retaliating?

Imagine a Venezuelan refugee illegally crosses the US-Mexico border next week and kills 18 US citizens with a bomb he carried across. Would Hannity have a guest on Fox News — say, Mike Johnson — arguing that “now is not the time, in the middle of the crisis, to talk about border security”?

Our emotional responses to these massacres are valid. Strike while the iron, and our blood, is running hot. Let our emotions fuel the urgency of our attempts to respond with overwhelmingly popular gun control legislation , and let Republicans head into elections in two weeks opposing them.

★

entry.content:
Alex Heath and Jay Peters, reporting for The Verge:

Meta's competitor to Elon Musk's X has hit “just under” 100 million monthly users since it was released in early July, CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced Wednesday during his company's quarterly earnings call.

“We're three months in now, and I'm very happy with the trajectory,” he said, echoing the bullish comments he made about how Threads is doing during a recent interview with The Verge. “We're now getting to the point where we're going to be focusing on growing the community further. From what we can tell, people love it so far.” [...]

“I've thought for a long time there should be a billion-person public conversations app that is a bit more positive,” Zuckerberg said on Wednesday's call. “I think that if we keep at this for a few more years, then I think we have a good chance of achieving our vision there.”

More and more, my social media attention is split between Mastodon and Threads. I like them both, for different reasons. But the one thing they share is that I enjoy using both of them.

Threads just keeps getting better: more and better features, and more activity. Exceedingly few jerks so far, too. It's embarrassing how bad those “ Turns out Threads is a bust ” takes were back in July.

entry.summary: Of the three component services whose standalone prices went up, TV+ and Arcade seem justified. News+, however, does not.
entry.content:
Joe Rossignol, MacRumors :

Apple today announced that it is increasing the prices of some of its subscription-based services, including Apple TV+, Apple Arcade, and Apple News+, for new and existing subscribers in the US and many other countries around the world .

The price changes in the US are as follows:

  • Apple TV+: $6.99 per month → $9.99 per month
  • Apple Arcade: $4.99 per month → $6.99 per month
  • Apple News+: $9.99 per month → $12.99 per month

对于按年订阅 Apple TV+ 的用户，价格相应从每年 69 美元上涨至每年 99 美元。

包含这些服务的 Apple One 捆绑包的价格也因此上涨：

  • 个人：每月 16.95 美元 → 每月 19.95 美元
  • 家庭：每月 22.95 美元 → 每月 25.95 美元
  • 高级：每月 32.95 美元 → 每月 37.95 美元

[...] Apple Music 和 Apple Fitness+ 今天没有涨价。

我本来想链接到苹果新闻编辑室宣布这些价格上涨的消息，但那里没有任何关于它们的消息。 Apple Newsroom是一个“仅限好消息”的公司博客。

在 Apple One 捆绑包层面，这些增长相当温和，但在独立层面，这些增长是引人注目的。 TV+ 现在的价格是四年前推出时的两倍。

Tom Warren 在 Twitter/X 上对流媒体服务不断上涨的价格做出了敏锐的观察：

如果 Apple TV、Netflix 和 Disney+ 继续提高价格，只会迫使更多人陷入盗版。令人惊讶的是，英国有多少人使用改装的 Fire TV 棒来观看盗版电视节目和电影。

我会对他的动词选择提出质疑，并建议“推动”而不是“强制”——没有人被迫盗版内容——但这一点是正确的。自从 20 年前 iTunes 音乐商店开业以来，正值通过 Napster 和类似平台进行 MP3 文件共享的鼎盛时期，我一直认为媒体盗版是一种谈判形式。这就像用户和公司之间的临时集体谈判，确定价格并定义媒体消费体验。

订阅定价需要一种微积分来找到产生最多收益的最佳点。将价格定得太低，可以减少盗版，但会浪费金钱。如果价格定得太高，你赚到的钱就会减少，因为更多的用户（原本可能以较低价格订阅的用户）会选择盗版。 （当然，有些人总是会选择盗版。试图找到一个价格来安抚他们是没有意义的。）

但定价并不是这个等式中的唯一因素。体验也是。走私的明显吸引力在于价格：零。但总是有点让人头疼。奇怪的应用程序和粗略的来源。史蒂夫·乔布斯在介绍 iTunes 音乐商店时强调了这一点：99 美分的价格很有吸引力，但不如免费那么有吸引力。但从 iTunes 搜索和下载音乐的整体体验比盗版要好得多，以至于你愿意为这些歌曲付费。

苹果仍然得到了这一点：他们使用其服务的应用程序通常很少有烦恼。您几乎永远不需要重新登录，因为您之前的登录已过期。我在 Apple TV 上使用的许多流媒体视频服务让我在那些令人难以置信的烦人的登录流程中经历了很多麻烦，在这些流程中，您必须使用其他设备（可能是您的手机，如果您是在沙发上），然后输入电视屏幕上的代码。然后你必须等待大约 20 秒，他们才会让你重新进入。然后几个月后，你必须因为无法解释的原因再次这样做。

每当官方服务让你观看不可跳过的广告时，每次他们糟糕的自定义视频播放器使快进或快退卡顿时，每次他们糟糕的应用程序感觉缓慢或忘记你在几天前暂停的电影中的位置时 - 那些小烦恼越积越多，与盗版内容相比，付费内容应提供的用户体验优势就会降低。

如果“盗版还是付费？”用户的争论只是关于价格，无数的人会盗版他们的音乐、内容和游戏。它更像是这样的：

  • 盗版：无需支付任何费用（好），对窃取内容感到内疚（坏），经历获取盗版内容以及破解游戏和应用程序副本的所有麻烦，并管理您自己的本地内容库（这些内容从这些内容中脱落）众所周知的卡车（坏）。此外，还存在法律纠纷的风险，您的互联网服务被禁用，或者如果某个盗版监管机构抓住您，您会感到非常尴尬（糟糕）。

  • 付费：支付每月的服务订阅费（坏），因为没有偷任何东西而感到内疚（好），避免获取和管理盗版媒体内容的麻烦（好），并享受使用的便捷性该服务的官方应用程序。

我没有在最后一项后面加上“（好）”或“（坏）”，因为一项服务与另一项服务之间的差异如此之大。多年来我盗取的唯一内容是那些无法通过合法渠道获得的稀有电影，例如原始星球大战三部曲的精彩“非专业”版本。除了我的钱多过理智之外，我在消费娱乐方面也非常懒惰。我根本不想工作来查找它、下载它或管理它。但有些流媒体应用程序太糟糕了，以至于让人感觉合法观看其内容与盗版内容一样费力。

关于 Netflix，有一点被大大低估了：他们总是提供出色的用户体验。他们的应用程序快速、可靠且设计精良。 Netflix 永远不会忘记我的登录凭据，也不会使其过期。您可以看出，Netflix 的每个人，包括特德·萨兰多斯和里德·黑斯廷斯，都关心整个用户体验。从文化上来说，Netflix 在这方面很像苹果：他们的公司 DNA 中融入了良好的品味。

至于今天苹果的价格上涨，我是一名 Apple One Premier 订户，我很好——当然，不高兴，但很好——每月额外支付 5 美元来购买我所得到的一切。 Of the three component services whose standalone prices went up, TV+ and Arcade seem justified. News+, however, does not.

几年来我一直在说 Apple TV+ 正在成为新的 HBO——一个专注于著名原创内容的频道，质量重于数量——现在 HBO在 Max 内部被淡化，这感觉比以往任何时候都更加真实。 Apple TV+ 提供源源不断的原创节目，我的家人非常喜欢。我很确定 TV+ 上我们最喜欢的节目比任何其他服务都多。与 Netflix 不同的是，苹果坚持保留所有好剧，并将其续订多季，让它们有一个令人满意的结局。 1 TV+ 的平均内容质量远高于 Disney+，Disney+ 一直在制作《阿索卡》和《秘密入侵》等令人尴尬的系列坦克大片，而相对令人失望的作品有《欧比旺·克诺比》 （一部夸张的六集连续剧，本应被削减为一部完整的两小时电影），只有偶尔出现像安多这样的宝石。虽然 Apple TV+ 长期以来因其相对缺乏旧图书馆内容而脱颖而出，但就原创新内容而言，它比 Amazon Prime、Hulu、Max 或落选者有更多的好东西（至少就我的口味而言）比如 Peacock 和 Paramount+。与新的原创内容相比，我只是不太关心对旧图书馆内容的流式访问，而且我认为大多数其他人也不会这样做。

至于Apple Arcade——我个人玩的电子游戏不多，但我在iPhone上玩的游戏越来越多地来自Arcade。没有广告，没有应用内购买付费获胜的欺骗行为，并且拥有不断增长的跨越各种类型的真正优秀游戏库。 7 美元/月感觉很公平。

但新闻+？ Apple News+ 的主要且明显的吸引力是可以访问《华尔街日报》等参与出版物的付费内容。这是一长串报纸和杂志。但实际的阅读体验往往很糟糕——Apple News 中大多数出版商的大多数文章都很糟糕，带有巨大的丑陋广告，每隔几个段落就将每篇文章分开。而且这些广告往往都是低级的骗局，几乎可笑。几周前，我在 Mastodon 上发布了其中一些的屏幕截图。看看他们就知道了。 2这些广告——以及它们的数量——看起来或感觉不像您应该在 10 美元/月的高级订阅中体验到的东西——更不用说 13 美元/月的新价格了。 News+ 提价的唯一理由是，苹果是否计划利用增加的订阅费收入来减少文章中的广告数量并提高其质量。

与盗版媒体、盗版游戏和应用程序一样，广告拦截是用户和发行商之间的谈判。至少对我来说，在网络浏览器中阅读同一篇文章（安装了阻止用户恶意广告的扩展程序）几乎总是比在 Apple News 中阅读要好得多的体验。鉴于 News+ 是一种价格不菲的付费订阅，用户体验方程式应该是相反的：在 Apple News 中阅读应该比在网络上阅读更好。但事实并非如此。然而苹果却在提高价格。

最后，我会带着轻微的烦恼但绝对零惊讶地指出，虽然苹果现在每年左右都在稳步提高其媒体内容服务的价格，但 iCloud 的数据存储层（无论是免费还是付费）自 2015 年以来一直保持不变，除了最高级别。 8年！媒体订阅价格的稳步上涨令人烦恼，但可以理解。大多数用户从不增加 iCloud 的存储量会让人感到顽固和恶意。

  1. 我说的是好节目，不是所有节目。 ↩︎

  2. 如果你滚动浏览我在 Mastodon 上的帖子的回复，你会看到一些人建议我之所以收到这样的底部广告，是因为我必须关闭“个性化广告”在“设置”→“隐私与安全”→“苹果广告”中。但我已经打开了个性化广告，并且已经打开了很长一段时间。这些都是苹果在 Apple News 上的好广告。我实在是太贪吃惩罚了，我实际上很想关掉个性化广告，看看广告是否会变得更糟。 ↩︎︎

entry.summary: 所以我只是在这里猜测，但我认为这个活动可能只是关于 iMac，只是 M2 的升级，也许还有一些设计变化，比如新鲜的颜色。如果这是 M3 的首次亮相，那就更有趣了，但我的直觉告诉我，这还没有发生。
entry.content:
丹·莫伦，《六种颜色》：

将此视为我以前从未见过的事情：晚上的苹果活动。该公司周二宣布将于太平洋时间 10 月 30 日星期一下午 5 点举办“Scary Fast”活动。

正如彭博社马克·古尔曼（Mark Gurman）本周末报道的那样，人们普遍预计这次活动将推出新款 Mac：这笔钱似乎是在更新的 24 英寸 iMac 上，不过也可能会发布其他产品。

在东部时间晚上 8 点/太平洋时间下午 5 点广播活动是一项新鲜事，但我们仍处于预先录制主题演讲时代的早期阶段。至少可以说，这很不寻常——让我想知道是否还有其他的事情可以让这个时机变得有意义。

如果是 iMac，升级到 M2 而不是 M3 我不会感到惊讶。 Gurman 报道称 iMac 将跳过 M2，直接转向 M3，但该报道可以追溯到2022 年6 月：

除了 Mac 和 iPad Pro 之外，我预计 M2 还会出现在另一个地方：苹果的混合现实耳机。据我所知，该设备的最新内部版本运行基础 M2 芯片以及 16 GB 的 RAM。 [...]

苹果公司还已经在开发 M2 的继任者 M3，并且该公司计划最早在明年更新代号为 J513 的 13 英寸 MacBook Air 和 15 英寸 MacBook Air 时使用该芯片。 J515，一款代号为 J433 的新 iMac，可能还有一款仍处于早期开发阶段的 12 英寸笔记本电脑。

他关于 Vision Pro 使用 M2 的说法是正确的 - 请记住，那是在它宣布之前整整一年 - 但我觉得 M3 芯片在 iMac 中首次亮相并不合适。 Gurman 还指出，MacBook Pro（无论是不那么“专业”的 13 英寸型号，还是真正专业的 14 英寸和 16 英寸型号）目前都供不应求，其中- 大多数配置的发货日期为 11 月。但感觉 M3 Pro/Max 芯片开始发货还为时过早，因为 A17 Pro（M3 可能基于该芯片）上个月才开始发货。鉴于我听说台积电的 3nm 生产能力——尤其是获得晶圆——我认为他们的手上已经忙着为 iPhone 15 Pro 生产 A17 Pro 芯片了。

所以我只是在这里猜测，但我认为这次活动可能只是关于 iMac，升级到 M2，也许还有一些设计变化——比如，比如新鲜的颜色。如果这是 M3 的首次亮相，那就更有趣了，但我的直觉告诉我，这还没有发生。

另外：在售价 3,500 美元的 Vision Pro（配备 M2）之前几个月开始推出售价 1,300 美元的基于 M3 的 iMac（或售价 1,000 美元的 iPad Pro），感觉有点尴尬。对我来说，基于 M3 的 Mac 和 iPad 只会在 Vision Pro之后推出，这很自然，因此当 Vision Pro 发布时，M2 仍然是“当前”的苹果芯片一代。

但是：这次活动的名字是“Scary Fast”，所以也许是关于M3系列的首次亮相？我仍然不认为他们会准备好 M3 Pro/Max 芯片，但也许这对所有使用常规 M2 的 Mac 来说都是一次更新（对于 iMac 来说，是 M1）？

因此，看起来古尔曼将在“今年会推出新 Mac 吗？”这一问题上击败郭明池。雷霆穹顶的对决，但有趣的是，似乎没有人知道到底会发生什么。

后记

好的，这是一个将所有拼图拼凑在一起的吐球想法：

  • 普通 24 英寸 iMac 升级至 M2。
  • 这些新的 iMac 也可能是那些据称用于 iPhone 15的颜色匹配的编织 USB-C 电缆的来源。所有 iPhone 15 型号都配备纯白色编织电缆，但现有的 M1 iMac 配备有趣的颜色 -匹配的闪电电缆。
  • 新款“pro”iMac 推出，配备 M2 Pro 和 M2 Max 芯片，与当前 14 英寸和 16 英寸 MacBook Pro（今年年初才推出）中的芯片相同。也许这些假设的 iMac Pro 也会有更大的显示屏？ 27 英寸可以匹配 Studio Display 和旧的基于英特尔的“大”iMac。

M2 Pro 和 Max iMac 可以证明“快得吓人”，而普通的 M2 iMac 减速带则不然。这仍然允许 Vision Pro 在“明年初”推出，而 M2 仍然是当前的苹果芯片一代。这也与传闻中的台积电 3nm 产能在不久的将来几乎完全致力于满足 iPhone 15 Pro 的需求相吻合。

entry.content: ; Speaking of Mark Gurman, he has an interesting bit about Apple's AI efforts in his latest Power On column : 该公司还有一些工作要做。去年，当 OpenAI 的 ChatGPT 像火箭一样腾飞时，苹果基本上处于观望状态。它看到谷歌和微软公司推出了其搜索引擎的生成人工智能版本，这些引擎对用户的查询给出了令人信服的类人响应。微软还用更智能的助手更新了 Windows 应用程序，亚马逊公司也推出了 Alexa 的人工智能增强版。 一直以来，苹果唯一值得注意的人工智能版本是 iOS 17 中改进的自动更正系统。 我认为 iOS 17 中改进的自动更正是一项主要功能——在我的使用中，这显然是一项改进，而且自动更正是几乎每个 iOS 用户每天、几乎每个应用程序中都使用的功能。它是整个操作系统中最常用和最重要的功能之一。我还认为苹果在照片中的人工智能功能方面做了一些出色的工作。照片中的搜索功能非常好用。 但我认为古尔曼的总结确实抓住了一个基本事实。如果我问你“哪些公司处于人工智能产品的最前沿？”，我怀疑你会把苹果列入名单。事实证明，人工智能非常有用，但它还是一个新兴领域，苹果需要尽快跻身该名单，以免他们的产品在竞争中开始落后。 “哪些公司最擅长将人工智能集成到产品中？”就像“哪些公司最擅长大规模制造硬件？”以及“哪些公司最擅长人机界面设计？” 古尔曼继续说道： 现在，首席执行官蒂姆库克表示，苹果多年来一直致力于生成人工智能技术。但我可以明确地告诉你，苹果高管对行业突如其来的人工智能热潮感到措手不及，从去年底开始就一直在忙着弥补失去的时间。 一位知情人士告诉 Power On：“对此有很多担忧，内部认为这是一个相当大的失误。” 正如我在 7 月份首次报道的那样，该公司构建了自己的大型语言模型，称为 Ajax，并推出了一个名为“Apple GPT”的内部聊天机器人来测试其功能。下一步关键是确定该技术是否能够应对竞争对手，以及苹果如何将其实际应用到其产品中。 我从库比蒂诺的小鸟那里听到的消息并不是已经出现了失误。苹果几乎从来没有走在此类产品的最前沿。他们是一家有目的的公司。与任何新技术一样，他们的目标是以有意义的方式最好地将其集成到产品中，而不是首先。这就是为什么他们不会因为错过任何与人工智能相关的事情而感到内心焦虑。 The anxiety inside Apple is that many people inside do not believe Apple's own AI/ML team can deliver, but that the company — if only for privacy reasons — will only use what comes from its ow
